cleaned_text: Louis Pasteur Louis Pasteur |Born||27 December 1822| of Sciences](/wiki/Foreign_Associate_of_the_National_Academy_of_Sciences)(1883) [Cameron Prize for Therapeutics of the September 1895) was a French [chemist](/wiki/Chemist) and [microbiologist](/wiki/Microbiologist) renowned for his discoveries of the principles of [vaccination](/wiki/Vaccination), [microbial fermentation](/wiki/Fermentation), and [pasteurization](/wiki/Pasteurization), the last of which was named after him. His research in chemistry led to remarkable breakthroughs in the understanding of the causes and preventions of [diseases](/wiki/Diseases), which laid down the foundations of hygiene, public health and much of modern medicine. [[7]](#cite_note-Ligon-7) Pasteur's works are credited with saving millions of lives through the developments of vaccines for [rabies](/wiki/Rabies) and [anthrax](/wiki/Anthrax). He is regarded as one of the founders of modern [bacteriology](/wiki/Bacteriology) and has been honored as the "father of bacteriology" [[8]](#cite_note-8) and Leeuwenhoek](/wiki/Antonie_van_Leeuwenhoek)). [[13]](#cite_note-13) Pasteur was responsible for disproving the doctrine of [spontaneous generation](/wiki/Spontaneous_generation). Under the auspices of the [French Academy of Sciences](/wiki/French_Academy_of_Sciences), his experiment demonstrated that in sterilized and sealed flasks, nothing ever developed; conversely, in sterilized but open flasks, microorganisms could grow. [[14]](#cite_note-seckbach-14) For this experiment, the academy awarded him the Alhumbert Prize carrying 2,500 [francs](/wiki/Francs) in 1862. Pasteur is also regarded as one of the fathers of [germ theory of diseases](/wiki/Germ_theory_of_diseases), which was a minor medical concept at the time. [[15]](#cite_note-ullmann-15) His many experiments showed that diseases could be prevented by killing or stopping germs, thereby directly supporting the germ theory and its application in clinical medicine. He is best known to the general public for his invention of the technique of treating [milk](/wiki/Milk) and [wine](/wiki/Wine) to stop bacterial contamination, a process now called pasteurization. Pasteur also made significant [discoveries](#Molecular_asymmetry) in chemistry, most notably on the molecular basis for the [asymmetry](/wiki/Asymmetry) of certain [crystals](/wiki/Crystals) and [racemization](/wiki/Racemization). Early in his career, his investigation of [sodium ammonium tartrate](/wiki/Sodium_ammonium_tartrate) initiated the field of [optical isomerism](/wiki/Chirality_(chemistry)). This work had a profound effect on structural chemistry, with eventual implications for many areas including [medicinal chemistry](/wiki/Medicinal_chemistry). He was the director of the [Pasteur Institute](/wiki/Pasteur_Institute), established in 1887, until his death, and his body was interred in a vault beneath the institute. Although Pasteur made groundbreaking experiments, his reputation became associated with various controversies. Historical reassessment of his notebook revealed that he practiced deception to overcome his rivals. [[16]](#cite_note-Geison1995-16) [[17]](#cite_note-17) Education and early life Louis Pasteur was born on 27 December 1822, in [Dole, Jura](/wiki/Dole,_Jura), France, to a [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic) family of a poor [tanner](/wiki/Tanner_(occupation)). [[18]](#cite_note-catholic_intro-18) He was the third child of Jean-Joseph Pasteur and Jeanne-Etiennette Roqui. The family moved to to [Arbois](/wiki/Arbois) in and [dysgraphic](/wiki/Dysgraphic). [[22]](#cite_note-22) [[23]](#cite_note-23) [[24]](#cite_note-24) He was an average student in his early years, and not particularly academic, as his interests were [fishing](/wiki/Fishing) and [sketching](/wiki/Sketch_(drawing)). [[18]](#cite_note-catholic_intro-18) He drew many pastels and portraits of his parents, friends and neighbors. [[25]](#cite_note-25) Pasteur attended secondary school at the Collège d'Arbois. [[26]](#cite_note-26) In October 1838, he left for Paris to enroll in a boarding school, but became homesick and returned in November. [[27]](#cite_note-27) In 1839, he entered the [Collège Royal](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coll%C3%A8ge_Victor-Hugo) at [Besançon](/wiki/Besan%C3%A7on) to study philosophy and earned his Bachelor of Letters degree in 1840. [[28]](#cite_note-28) He was appointed a tutor at the Besançon college while continuing a degree science course with special mathematics. [[29]](#cite_note-29) He failed his first examination in 1841. He managed to pass the [baccalauréat scientifique](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baccalaur%C3%A9at_scientifique) (general science) degree from Dijon, where he earned his Bachelor of Science in Mathematics degree (Bachelier ès Sciences Mathématiques) in 1842, [[4]](#cite_note-Math-4) but with a mediocre grade in chemistry. [[30]](#cite_note-30) Later in 1842, Pasteur took the entrance test for the [École Normale Supérieure](/wiki/%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_(Paris)). [[31]](#cite_note-31) He passed the first set of tests, but because his ranking was low, Pasteur decided not to continue and try again next year. [[32]](#cite_note-32) He went back to the Parisian boarding school to prepare for the test. He also attended classes at the [Lycée Saint-Louis](/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Saint-Louis) and lectures of [Jean-Baptiste Dumas](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Dumas) at the [Sorbonne](/wiki/University_of_Paris). [[33]](#cite_note-33) In 1843, he passed the test with a high ranking and entered the [École Normale Supérieure](/wiki/%C3%89cole_normale_sup%C3%A9rieure_(Paris)). [[34]](#cite_note-34) In 1845 sciences](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Licence_de_biologie) degree. [[35]](#cite_note-Debré_and_Forster_p._502-35) In 1846, he was appointed professor of physics at the Collège de Tournon (now called [Lycée Gabriel-Faure](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Gabriel-Faure)) in [Ardèche](/wiki/Ard%C3%A8che). But the chemist him back at the École as a graduate laboratory assistant (agrégé préparateur). [[36]](#cite_note-36) He joined Balard and simultaneously started his research in [crystallography](/wiki/Crystallography) and in 1847, he submitted his two theses, one in chemistry and the other in physics: (a) Chemistry Thesis: "Recherches sur la capacité Application de la polarisation rotatoire des liquides à solution de diverses questions de chimie." [[5]](#cite_note-Thesis-5) [[35]](#cite_note-Debré_and_Forster_p._502-35) [[37]](#cite_note-37) After serving briefly as professor of physics at the Dijon [Lycée](/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e) in 1848, he became professor of chemistry at the [University of Strasbourg](/wiki/University_of_Strasbourg), [[38]](#cite_note-38) where he met and courted [Marie Laurent](/wiki/Marie_Laurent), daughter of the university's [rector](/wiki/Rector_(academia)) in 1849. They were married on 29 May 1849, [[39]](#cite_note-39) and together had five children, only two of whom survived to adulthood; [[40]](#cite_note-40) the other three died of [typhoid](/wiki/Typhoid). Career Pasteur was appointed professor of chemistry at the University of Strasbourg in 1848, and became the chair of chemistry in 1852. [[41]](#cite_note-41) In February 1854, so that he would have time to carry out work that could earn him the title of correspondent of the Institute, he got three months' paid leave with the help of a medical certificate of convenience. [[42]](#cite_note-42) He extended the leave until 1 August, the date of the start of the exams. "I tell the Minister that I will go and do the examinations so as not to increase the embarrassment of the service. It is also so as not to leave to another a sum of 6 or 700 francs". [[43]](#cite_note-43) In this same year 1854, he was named dean of the new faculty of sciences at [University of Lille](/wiki/University_of_Lille), where he began his studies on fermentation. [[44]](#cite_note-Chirality-44) It was on this occasion that Pasteur uttered his oft-quoted remark: "dans les champs que les esprits préparés" ("In the field of observation, chance favors only the prepared mind"). [[45]](#cite_note-45) In 1857, he moved to Paris as the director of scientific studies at the [École Normale Supérieure](/wiki/%C3%89cole_Normale_Sup%C3%A9rieure) where he took control from 1858 to 1867 and introduced a series of reforms to improve the standard of scientific work. The examinations became more rigid, which led to better results, greater competition, and increased prestige. Many of his decrees, however, were rigid and authoritarian, leading to two serious student revolts. During "the bean revolt" he decreed that a mutton stew, which students had refused to eat, would be served and eaten every Monday. On another occasion he threatened to expel any student caught smoking, and 73 of the 80 students in the school resigned. [[46]](#cite_note-Debre-46) In 1863, he was appointed professor of geology, physics, and chemistry at the [École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts](/wiki/%C3%89cole_nationale_sup%C3%A9rieure_des_Beaux-Arts), a position he held until his resignation in 1867. In 1867, he became the chair of organic chemistry at the Sorbonne, [[47]](#cite_note-Debré_&_Patrice_pp._505-7-47) but he later gave up the position because of poor health. [[48]](#cite_note-48) In 1867, the École Normale's laboratory of physiological chemistry was created at Pasteur's request, [[47]](#cite_note-Debré_&_Patrice_pp._505-7-47) and he was the laboratory's director from 1867 to 1888. [[49]](#cite_note-49) In Paris, he established the Pasteur Institute in 1887, in which he was its director for the rest of his life. [[9]](#cite_note-fein-9) [[50]](#cite_note-van-50) Research Molecular asymmetry In Pasteur's early work as a [chemist](/wiki/Chemist), beginning at the École Normale Supérieure, and continuing at Strasbourg and Lille, he examined the chemical, optical and crystallographic properties of a group of compounds known as [tartrates](/wiki/Tartrates). [[51]](#cite_note-Flack-51) He resolved a problem concerning the nature of [tartaric acid](/wiki/Tartaric_acid) in 1848. [[52]](#cite_note-52) [[53]](#cite_note-53) [[54]](#cite_note-54) [[55]](#cite_note-Gal-55) A solution of this compound derived from living things [rotated](/wiki/Optical_rotation) the [plane of polarization](/wiki/Plane_of_polarization) of light passing through it. [[51]](#cite_note-Flack-51) The problem was that tartaric acid derived by [chemical synthesis](/wiki/Chemical_synthesis) had no such effect, even though its chemical reactions were identical and its elemental composition was the same. [[56]](#cite_note-cohn-56) Pasteur noticed that crystals of tartrates had small faces. Then he observed that, in [racemic mixtures](/wiki/Racemic_mixture) of tartrates, half of the crystals were right-handed and half were left-handed. In solution, the right-handed compound was [dextrorotatory](/wiki/Dextrorotatory), and the left-handed one was levorotatory. [[51]](#cite_note-Flack-51) Pasteur determined that optical activity related to the shape of the crystals, and that an asymmetric internal arrangement of the molecules of the compound was responsible for twisting the light. [[44]](#cite_note-Chirality-44) The (2R,3R)- and (2S,3S)- tartrates were isometric, non-superposable mirror images of each other. This was the first time anyone had demonstrated [molecular chirality](/wiki/Chirality_(chemistry)), and also the first explanation of [isomerism](/wiki/Isomer). [[51]](#cite_note-Flack-51) Some historians consider Pasteur's work in this area to be his "most profound and most original contributions to science", and his "greatest scientific discovery." [[51]](#cite_note-Flack-51) Fermentation and germ theory of diseases Pasteur was motivated to investigate fermentation while working at Lille. In 1856 a local wine manufacturer, M. Bigot, whose son was one of Pasteur's students, sought for his advice on the problems of making beetroot alcohol and souring. [[57]](#cite_note-57) [[7]](#cite_note-Ligon-7) Pasteur began his research in the topic by repeating and confirming works of [Theodor Schwann](/wiki/Theodor_Schwann), who demonstrated a decade earlier that yeast were alive. According to his son-in-law, René Vallery-Radot, in August 1857 Pasteur sent a paper about lactic acid fermentation to the Société des Sciences de Lille, but the paper was read three months later. [[58]](#cite_note-58) A memoire was subsequently published on 30 November 1857. [[59]](#cite_note-59) In the memoir, he developed his ideas stating that: "I intend to establish that, just as there is an alcoholic ferment, the yeast of beer, which is found everywhere that sugar is decomposed into alcohol and carbonic acid, so also there is a particular ferment, a [lactic yeast](/wiki/Lactic_acid_bacteria), always present when [sugar becomes lactic acid](/wiki/Lactic_acid_fermentation)." [[60]](#cite_note-manchester2007-60) Pasteur also wrote about alcoholic fermentation. [[61]](#cite_note-61) It was published in full form in 1858. [[62]](#cite_note-62) [[63]](#cite_note-63) [Jöns Jacob Berzelius](/wiki/J%C3%B6ns_Jacob_Berzelius) and [Justus von Liebig](/wiki/Justus_von_Liebig) had proposed the theory that fermentation was caused by decomposition. Pasteur demonstrated that this theory was incorrect, and that yeast was responsible for fermentation to produce alcohol from sugar. [[64]](#cite_note-Barnett-64) He also demonstrated that, when a different microorganism contaminated the wine, lactic acid was produced, making the wine sour. [[7]](#cite_note-Ligon-7) In 1861, Pasteur observed that less sugar fermented per part of yeast when the yeast was exposed to air. [[64]](#cite_note-Barnett-64) The lower rate of fermentation aerobically became known as the [Pasteur effect](/wiki/Pasteur_effect). [[65]](#cite_note-65) Pasteur's research also showed that the growth of micro-organisms was responsible for spoiling beverages, such as beer, wine and milk. With this established, he invented a process in which liquids such as milk were heated to a temperature between 60 and 100 °C. [[66]](#cite_note-Bowden-66) This killed most bacteria and moulds already present within them. Pasteur and [Claude Bernard](/wiki/Claude_Bernard) completed tests on blood and urine on 20 April 1862. [[67]](#cite_note-67) Pasteur patented the process, to fight the "diseases" of wine, in 1865. [[66]](#cite_note-Bowden-66) The method became known as [pasteurization](/wiki/Pasteurization), and was soon applied to beer and milk. [[68]](#cite_note-Nelson2009-68) Beverage contamination led Pasteur to the idea that micro-organisms infecting animals and humans cause disease. He proposed preventing the entry of micro-organisms into the human body, leading [Joseph Lister](/wiki/Joseph_Lister,_1st_Baron_Lister) to develop [antiseptic](/wiki/Antiseptic) methods in surgery. [[69]](#cite_note-Listerine-69) In 1866, Pasteur published Etudes sur le Vin, about the diseases of wine, and he published Etudes sur la Bière in 1876, concerning the diseases of beer. [[64]](#cite_note-Barnett-64) In the early 19th century, [Agostino Bassi](/wiki/Agostino_Bassi) had shown that [muscardine](/wiki/Muscardine) was caused by a fungus that infected silkworms. [[70]](#cite_note-Hatcher-70) Since 1853, two diseases called [pébrine](/wiki/P%C3%A9brine) and [flacherie](/wiki/Flacherie) had been infecting great numbers of [silkworms](/wiki/Silkworm) in southern France, and by 1865 they were causing huge losses to farmers. In 1865, Pasteur went to [Alès](/wiki/Al%C3%A8s) and worked for five years until 1870. [[71]](#cite_note-Berche-71) [[72]](#cite_note-Schwartz-72) Silkworms with pébrine were covered in corpuscles. In the first three years, Pasteur thought that the corpuscles were a symptom of the disease. In 1870, he concluded that the corpuscles were the cause of pébrine (it is now known that the cause is a [microsporidian](/wiki/Microsporidian)). [[70]](#cite_note-Hatcher-70) Pasteur also showed that the disease was hereditary. [[73]](#cite_note-Keim_pp._87-88-73) Pasteur developed a system to prevent pébrine: after the female moths laid their eggs, the moths were turned into a pulp. The pulp was examined with a microscope, and if corpuscles were observed, the eggs were destroyed. [[74]](#cite_note-74) [[73]](#cite_note-Keim_pp._87-88-73) Pasteur concluded that bacteria caused flacherie. The primary cause is currently thought to be viruses. [[70]](#cite_note-Hatcher-70) The spread of flacherie could be accidental or hereditary. Hygiene could be used to prevent accidental flacherie. Moths whose digestive cavities did not contain the microorganisms causing flacherie were used to lay eggs, preventing hereditary flacherie. [[75]](#cite_note-75) Spontaneous generation Following his fermentation experiments, Pasteur demonstrated that the skin of grapes was the natural source of yeasts, and that sterilized grapes and grape juice never fermented. He drew grape juice from under the skin with sterilized needles, and also covered grapes with sterilized cloth. Both experiments could not produce wine in sterilized containers. [[7]](#cite_note-Ligon-7) His findings and ideas were against the prevailing notion of [spontaneous generation](/wiki/Spontaneous_generation). He received a particularly stern criticism from [Félix Archimède Pouchet](/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Archim%C3%A8de_Pouchet), who was director of the [Rouen Museum of Natural History](/wiki/Mus%C3%A9um_d%27Histoire_Naturelle_de_Rouen). To settle the debate between the eminent scientists, the French Academy of Sciences offered the Alhumbert Prize carrying 2,500 [francs](/wiki/Francs) to whoever could experimentally demonstrate for or against the doctrine. [[76]](#cite_note-Magner-76) [[77]](#cite_note-77) [[78]](#cite_note-78) Pouchet stated that air everywhere could cause spontaneous generation of living organisms in liquids. [[79]](#cite_note-79) In the late 1850s, he performed experiments and claimed that they were evidence of spontaneous generation. [[80]](#cite_note-porter-80) [[76]](#cite_note-Magner-76) [Francesco Redi](/wiki/Francesco_Redi) and [Lazzaro Spallanzani](/wiki/Lazzaro_Spallanzani) had provided some evidence against spontaneous generation in the 17th and 18th centuries, respectively. Spallanzani's experiments in 1765 suggested that air contaminated broths with bacteria. In the 1860s, Pasteur repeated Spallanzani's experiments, but Pouchet reported a different result using a different broth. [[71]](#cite_note-Berche-71) Pasteur performed several experiments to disprove spontaneous generation. He placed boiled liquid in a flask and let hot air enter the flask. Then he closed the flask, and no organisms grew in it. [[80]](#cite_note-porter-80) In another experiment, when he opened flasks containing boiled liquid, dust entered the flasks, causing organisms to grow in some of them. The number of flasks in which organisms grew was lower at higher altitudes, showing that air at high altitudes contained less dust and fewer organisms. [[7]](#cite_note-Ligon-7) [[81]](#cite_note-81) Pasteur also used [swan neck flasks](/wiki/Swan_neck_flask) containing a fermentable liquid. Air was allowed to enter the flask via a long curving tube that made dust particles stick to it. Nothing grew in the broths unless the flasks were tilted, making the liquid touch the contaminated walls of the neck. This showed that the living organisms that grew in such broths came from outside, on dust, rather than spontaneously generating within the liquid or from the action of pure air. [[7]](#cite_note-Ligon-7) [[82]](#cite_note-82) These were some of the most important experiments disproving the theory of spontaneous generation. Pasteur gave a series of five presentations of his findings before the French Academy of Sciences in 1881, which were published in 1882 as Mémoire Sur les corpuscules organisés qui Examen la doctrine des générations spontanées (Account of Organized Corpuscles Existing in the Atmosphere: Examining the Doctrine of Spontaneous Generation). [[83]](#cite_note-83) [[84]](#cite_note-84) Pasteur won the Alhumbert Prize in 1862. [[80]](#cite_note-porter-80) He concluded that: Never will the doctrine of spontaneous generation recover from the mortal blow of this simple experiment. There is no known circumstance in which it can be confirmed that microscopic beings came into the world without germs, without parents similar to themselves. [[7]] [[72]] Silkworm disease In 1865, [Jean-Baptiste Dumas](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Dumas), chemist, senator and former Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, asked Pasteur to study a new disease that was decimating [silkworm](/wiki/Bombyx_mori) farms from the south of France and Europe, the [pébrine](/wiki/P%C3%A9brine), characterized on a macroscopic scale by black spots and on a microscopic scale by the " [Cornalia](/wiki/Emilio_Cornalia) corpuscles". Pasteur accepted and made five long stays in [Alès](/wiki/Al%C3%A8s), between 7 June 1865 and 1869. [[85]](#cite_note-85) Initial errors Arriving in Alès, Pasteur familiarized himself with pébrine and also [[86]](#cite_note-86) with another disease of the silkworm, known earlier [[87]](#cite_note-87) than pebrine: [flacherie](/wiki/Flacherie) or dead-flat disease. Contrary, for example, to [Quatrefages](/wiki/Jean_Louis_Armand_de_Quatrefages_de_Br%C3%A9au), who coined the new word pébrine, [[88]](#cite_note-88) Pasteur made the mistake of believing that the two diseases were the same and even that most of the diseases of silkworms known up to that time were identical with each other and with pébrine. [[89]](#cite_note-89) It was in letters of 30 April and 21 May 1867 to Dumas that he first made the distinction between pébrine and flacherie. [[90]](#cite_note-90) He made another mistake: he began by denying the "parasitic" (microbial) nature of pébrine, which several scholars (notably [Antoine Béchamp](/wiki/Antoine_B%C3%A9champ)) [[91]](#cite_note-91) considered well established. Even a note published on 27 August 1866 by [Balbiani](/wiki/%C3%89douard-G%C3%A9rard_Balbiani), [[92]](#cite_note-92) which Pasteur at first seemed to welcome favourably [[93]](#cite_note-93) had no effect, at least immediately. [[94]](#cite_note-94) "Pasteur is mistaken. He would only change his mind in the course of 1867". [[95]](#cite_note-95) Victory over pébrine At a time where Pasteur had not yet understood the cause of the pébrine, he propagated an effective process to stop infections: a sample of chrysalises was chosen, they were crushed and the corpuscles were searched for in the crushed material; if the proportion of corpuscular pupae in the sample was very low, the chamber was considered good for reproduction. [[96]](#cite_note-96) This method of sorting "seeds" (eggs) is close to a method that Osimo had proposed a few years earlier, but whose trials had not been conclusive. [[97]](#cite_note-97) By this process, Pasteur curbs pébrine and saves many of the silk industry in the Cévennes. [[98]](#cite_note-98) [[99]](#cite_note-99) Flacherie resists In is overcome, flacherie still exerts its ravages". He attributed the persistence of flacherie to the fact that the farmers had not followed his advice. [[100]](#cite_note-100) In 1884, [Balbiani](/wiki/%C3%89douard-G%C3%A9rard_Balbiani), [[101]](#cite_note-101) who disregarded the theoretical value of Pasteur's work on silkworm diseases, acknowledged that his practical process had remedied the ravages of pébrine, but added that this result tended to be counterbalanced by the development of flacherie, which was less well known and more difficult to prevent. Despite Pasteur's success against pébrine, French sericulture had not been saved from damage. (See [fr:Sériciculture](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%A9riciculture) in the French Wikipedia.) Immunology and vaccination Chicken cholera Pasteur's first work on vaccine development was on [chicken cholera](/wiki/Chicken_cholera). He received the bacteria samples (later called Pasteurella multocida after him) from [Henry Toussaint](/wiki/Jean_Joseph_Henri_Toussaint). [[102]](#cite_note-Plotkin_pp._35-36-102) He started the study in 1877, and by the next year, was able to maintain a stable culture using broths. [[103]](#cite_note-:0-103) After another year of continuous culturing, he found that the bacteria were less pathogenic. Some of his culture samples could no longer induce the disease in healthy [chickens](/wiki/Chicken). In 1879, Pasteur, planning for holiday, instructed his assistant, [Charles Chamberland](/wiki/Charles_Chamberland) to inoculate the chickens with fresh bacteria culture. Chamberland forgot and went on holiday himself. On his return, he injected the month-old cultures to healthy chickens. The chickens showed some symptoms of infection, but instead of the infections being fatal, as they usually were, the chickens recovered completely. Chamberland assumed an error had been made, and wanted to discard the apparently faulty culture, but Pasteur stopped him. [[104]](#cite_note-104) [[105]](#cite_note-105) Pasteur injected the freshly recovered chickens with fresh bacteria that normally would kill other chickens; the chickens no longer showed any sign of infection. It was clear to him that the weakened bacteria had caused the chickens to become [immune](/wiki/Immune) to the disease. [[103]](#cite_note-:0-103) [[106]](#cite_note-Artenstein_p._75-106) In December 1880, Pasteur presented his results to the French Academy of Sciences as "Sur les maladies virulentes et vulgairement choléra des poules (On virulent diseases, and in particular on the disease commonly called chicken cholera)" and published it in the academy's journal ( [Comptes-Rendus hebdomadaires des séances de l'Académie des Sciences](/wiki/Comptes_rendus_de_l%27Acad%C3%A9mie_des_Sciences)). He attributed that the bacteria were weakened by contact with oxygen. [[102]](#cite_note-Plotkin_pp._35-36-102) He explained that bacteria kept in sealed containers never lost their virulence, and only those exposed to air in culture media could be used as vaccine. Pasteur introduced the term "attenuation" for this weakening of virulence as he presented before the academy, saying: We can diminish the microbe's virulence by changing the mode of culturing. This is the crucial point of my subject. I ask the Academy not to criticize, for the time being, the confidence of my proceedings that permit me to determine the microbe's attenuation, in order to save the independence of my studies and to better assure their progress... [In conclusion] I would like to point out to the Academy two main consequences to the facts presented: the hope to culture all microbes and to find a vaccine for all infectious diseases that have repeatedly afflicted humanity, and are a major burden on agriculture and breeding of domestic animals. [[107]] In fact, Pasteur's vaccine against chicken cholera was not regular in its effects and was a failure. [[108]](#cite_note-108) Anthrax In the 1870s, he applied this immunization method to [anthrax](/wiki/Anthrax), which affected [cattle](/wiki/Cattle), and aroused interest in combating other diseases. Pasteur cultivated bacteria from the blood of animals infected with anthrax. When he inoculated animals with the bacteria, anthrax occurred, proving that the bacteria was the cause of the disease. [[109]](#cite_note-109) Many cattle were dying of anthrax in "cursed fields". [[72]](#cite_note-Schwartz-72) Pasteur was told that sheep that died from anthrax were buried in the field. Pasteur thought that earthworms might have brought the bacteria to the surface. He found anthrax bacteria in earthworms' excrement, showing that he was correct. [[72]](#cite_note-Schwartz-72) He told the farmers not to bury dead animals in the fields. [[110]](#cite_note-110) Pasteur had been trying to develop the anthrax vaccine since 1877, soon after Robert Koch's discovery of the bacterium. [[107]](#cite_note-:1-107) On 12 July 1880, Henri Bouley read before the French Academy of Sciences a report from [Henry Toussaint](/wiki/Jean_Joseph_Henri_Toussaint), a [veterinary surgeon](/wiki/Veterinary_surgeon), who was not member of the academy. Toussaint had developed anthrax vaccine by killing the bacilli by heating at 55 °C for 10 minutes. He tested on eight dogs and 11 sheep, half of which died after inoculation. It was not a great success.
